facts.text: Three petitions presented to Supreme Court under article 32 for writs of habeas corpus for release of petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, J. These three petitions have been presented to this Court under article 32 of the Constitution of India praying for the issue of writs in the nature of habeas companypus for release of the petitioners who are respectively the President, Vice-President and Secretary of the Hindu Mahasabha of the Delhi State.

facts.text: Petitioners are President, Vice-President and Secretary of Hindu Mahasabha of Delhi State.

anchor.surface_text: petitioners who are respectively the President, Vice-President and Secretary of the Hindu Mahasabha of the Delhi State. The petitioners were arrested on 22nd August, 1950, by order of the District Magistrate, Delhi, made under sub-section  2  read with clause  a  sub-clause  i  of sub-section  1  of section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Petitioners arrested on 22nd August 1950 by order of District Magistrate Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners were arrested on 22nd August, 1950, by order of the District Magistrate, Delhi, made under sub-section  2  read with clause  a  sub-clause  i  of sub-section  1  of section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The order ran as follows Whereas I, Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate, Delhi, am satisfied that with a view to the maintenance of public order in Delhi it is necessary to do so, I Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate, Delhi, hereby order the detention of under sub-section  2  of section 3 1  a  ii  of the Preventive Detention Act.

facts.text: Arrest order made by Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate Delhi, under sub-section 2 read with clause a sub-clause i of sub-section 1 of section 3 of Preventive Detention Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: made under sub-section  2  read with clause  a  sub-clause  i  of sub-section  1  of section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The order ran as follows Whereas I, Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate, Delhi, am satisfied that with a view to the maintenance of public order in Delhi it is necessary to do so, I Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate, Delhi, hereby order the detention of under sub-section  2  of section 3 1  a  ii  of the Preventive Detention Act. Given under my seal and signature.

facts.text: Detention order for maintenance of public order in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The order ran as follows Whereas I, Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate, Delhi, am satisfied that with a view to the maintenance of public order in Delhi it is necessary to do so, I Rameshwar Dayal, District Magistrate, Delhi, hereby order the detention of under sub-section  2  of section 3 1  a  ii  of the Preventive Detention Act. Given under my seal and signature. The grounds of detention companymunicated to the petitioners were in identical terms, save as to the dates on which the speeches were said to have been made, and read thus In pursuance of section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act you are hereby informed that the grounds on which the detention order dated 22nd August, 1950, has been made against you are that your speeches generally in the past and particularly on August, 1950, at public meetings in Delhi has been such as to excite disaffection between Hindus and Muslims and thereby prejudice the maintenance of public order in Delhi and that in order to prevent you from making such speeches it is necessary to make the said order.

facts.text: Grounds of detention: speeches generally in past and particularly on August 1950 at public meetings in Delhi such as to excite disaffection between Hindus and Muslims, prejudicing public order.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention companymunicated to the petitioners were in identical terms, save as to the dates on which the speeches were said to have been made, and read thus In pursuance of section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act you are hereby informed that the grounds on which the detention order dated 22nd August, 1950, has been made against you are that your speeches generally in the past and particularly on August, 1950, at public meetings in Delhi has been such as to excite disaffection between Hindus and Muslims and thereby prejudice the maintenance of public order in Delhi and that in order to prevent you from making such speeches it is necessary to make the said order.

facts.text: Petitioners applied to High Court at Simla under article 226, petitions dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners applied to the High Court at Simla for similar relief under article 226 of the Constitution, but the petitions were dismissed. It appears to have been companytended before the learned Judges  Khosla and Falshaw JJ.  who heard those petitions that although this Court held in A. K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras 1950 S.C.R. 88 that the provisions of section 3 of the Act were companystitutional and valid, detention under that section was ultra vires and illegal where, as here, it was based on the ground of making speeches prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: High Court petitions heard by Khosla and Falshaw JJ., dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to have been companytended before the learned Judges  Khosla and Falshaw JJ.  who heard those petitions that although this Court held in A. K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras 1950 S.C.R. 88 that the provisions of section 3 of the Act were companystitutional and valid, detention under that section was ultra vires and illegal where, as here, it was based on the ground of making speeches prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Petitioners are Prof. Ram Singh (President), Bal Raj Khanna (Vice-President), Ram Nath Kalia (Secretary) of Delhi State Hindu Mahasabha.

anchor.surface_text: Mahajan, J. These three petitions under article 32 of the Constitution of India were presented by Prof. Ram Singh, Bal Raj Khanna and Ram Nath Kalia, all three of whom were arrested and placed in detention on the 22nd August, 1950, under the orders of the District Magistrate of Delhi, under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950. The petitioners are respectively, the President, Vice-President and the Secretary of the Delhi State Hindu Mahasabha.

facts.text: Prof. Ram Singh, Bal Raj Khanna, Ram Nath Kalia arrested on 22nd August 1950 under orders of District Magistrate Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are respectively, the President, Vice-President and the Secretary of the Delhi State Hindu Mahasabha. The grounds of detention supplied to them are almost identical. Those furnished to Prof. Ram Singh read as follows - In pursuance of section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act, you are hereby informed that the grounds on which the detention order dated August 22, 1950, has been made against you are that your speeches generally in the past and particularly on the 13th and 15th August, 1950, at public meetings in Delhi have been such as to excite disaffection between Hindus and Muslims and thereby prejudice the maintenance of public order in Delhi and that in order to prevent you from making such speeches it is necessary to make the said order.

facts.text: Grounds for Prof. Ram Singh: speeches generally past and particularly 13th and 15th August 1950 at public meetings Delhi exciting disaffection Hindus-Muslims.

anchor.surface_text: Those furnished to Prof. Ram Singh read as follows - In pursuance of section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act, you are hereby informed that the grounds on which the detention order dated August 22, 1950, has been made against you are that your speeches generally in the past and particularly on the 13th and 15th August, 1950, at public meetings in Delhi have been such as to excite disaffection between Hindus and Muslims and thereby prejudice the maintenance of public order in Delhi and that in order to prevent you from making such speeches it is necessary to make the said order. You are further informed that you are entitled to make a representation against your detention to the State Government, that is, the Chief Commissioner, Delhi.

facts.text: Grounds for Bal Raj Khanna: speeches particularly on 15th August 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds supplied to the other two petitioners were the same except that in the case of Bal Raj Khanna only the 15th August, 1950, is mentioned as the date on which the public speech was made, and in the case of the third petitioner, it is only the 13th August, 1950.

facts.text: Grounds for Ram Nath Kalia: speeches particularly on 13th August 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and in the case of the third petitioner, it is only the 13th August, 1950. Mr. Hardy on behalf of the petitioners inter alia urged that the grounds served on the petitioners as justifying the orders of detention are quite indefinite and are number sufficient to enable them to make an effective representation to the State Government against their detention and that being so, their detention is illegal.

facts.text: District Magistrate filed affidavit stating satisfied that petitioners' speeches excited disaffection between Hindus and Muslims.

anchor.surface_text: An affidavit of the District Magistrate was placed before us at the hearing of the cases stating that he was satisfied that the petitioners speeches generally, and particularly those made on the 13th and 15th August, 1950, at public meetings in Delhi had been such as to excite disaffection between Hindus and Muslims.

facts.text: Petitioners alleged orders made for collateral purpose of stifling political opposition.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was said that the petitioners were prominent members of a political organisation which was opposed to the ideals and policies of the party in power, and that the orders of detention were made for the companylateral purpose of stifling effective political opposition and legitimate criticism of the policies pursued by the Congress Party and had numberhing to do with the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: District Magistrate denied mala fides in affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate has, in his affidavit filed in these proceedings, stated that, from the materials placed before him by persons experienced in investigating matters of this kind, he was satisfied that it was necessary to detain the petitioners with a view to preventing them from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order, and he has emphatically repudiated the purpose and motive imputed to him.

facts.text: Petitions dismissed by Supreme Court (majority).

anchor.surface_text: The petitions are dismissed.

facts.text: Mahajan J dissents, holds detention illegal due to vague grounds.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above I venture to dissent from the opinion of the majority of the Court with great respect and hold that the detention orders above mentioned are illegal. I accordingly order the release of the petitioners.

facts.text: Bose J agrees with Mahajan J, holds detentions illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Bose, J. I agree with my brother Mahajan whose judgment I have had the advantage of reading, and with the utmost respect find myself unable to accept the majority view. I am of opinion that these petitioners should all be released on the ground that their detentions are illegal.

facts.text: Petitioners detained over six months at time of hearing.

anchor.surface_text: No reason whatsoever has been stated in the affidavit of the District Magistrate for number disclosing the words used by the detenus even after this length of time and from which he drew the companyclusions on the basis of which he has kept the petitioners under detention for a period well over six months or more.

issues.text: Whether preventive detention under section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, to prevent speeches prejudicial to the maintenance of public order is invalid as it imposes a restriction on freedom of speech under Article 19(1)(a) not authorised by Article 19(2)?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the petitioners Mr. Hardy submitted that the provisions of the Act should number be used to prevent a citizen from making speeches though they might be companysidered to be prejudicial to the maintenance of public order, for maintenance of public order is number a purpose for which imposition of a restriction on freedom of speech is authorised by the Constitution, as held by this Court in the Cross-Roads 1950 S.C.R. 594 and the Organizer 1950 S.C.R. 605 cases.

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention communicated under section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act are vague and insufficient to enable the petitioners to make an effective representation as required by Article 22(5)?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Hardy next companytended that, in view of the recent decision of this Court in The State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya 1951 S.C.R. 167, the grounds of detention companymunicated to each of the petitioners must be held to be too vague and indefinite to enable them to make their representations to the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, and the requirements of clause  5  of article 22 number having thus been companyplied with, the petitioners were entitled to be set at liberty.

issues.text: Whether the detention orders are invalid for failing to specify the period of detention?

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged that the orders of detention were bad because they did number specify the period during which the petitioners were to be under detention. This point is number companycluded against the petitioners by the decision of this Court in Ujager Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 149 of 1950 and Jagjit Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 167 of 1950 where it was pointed out that as section 12 of the Act itself prescribed a maximum period of one year for detention thereunder, such orders companyld number be said to be of indefinite duration and unlawful on that ground.

issues.text: Whether the detention orders were motivated by mala fides to stifle political opposition rather than maintenance of public order?

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was said that the petitioners were prominent members of a political organisation which was opposed to the ideals and policies of the party in power, and that the orders of detention were made for the companylateral purpose of stifling effective political opposition and legitimate criticism of the policies pursued by the Congress Party and had numberhing to do with the maintenance of public order.

issues.text: Whether the grounds must include the substance or gist of the alleged prejudicial speeches to satisfy the requirements of Article 22(5) for making an effective representation?

anchor.surface_text: The question for decision is whether what is stated in the grounds is sufficient material on the basis of which the fundamental right companyferred on the petitioners by article 22 5  of the Constitution can be adequately exercised and whether without knowing the substance of the offending passages in the speeches from which the inference has been drawn by the District Magistrate it is possible to prove that this inference is number justified.

arguments.claim: Provisions of the Act should not be used to prevent speeches prejudicial to public order as it is not an authorized restriction under Article 19(2)

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the petitioners Mr. Hardy submitted that the provisions of the Act should number be used to prevent a citizen from making speeches though they might be companysidered to be prejudicial to the maintenance of public order, for maintenance of public order is number a purpose for which imposition of a restriction on freedom of speech is authorised by the Constitution, as held by this Court in the Cross-Roads 1950 S.C.R. 594 and the Organizer 1950 S.C.R. 605 cases.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in those cases this Court decided by a majority of 5 to 1 that unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it such law cannot fall within the reservation of clause  2  of article 19 although the restrictions which it seeks impose may have been companyceived generally in the interests if public order.

anchor.surface_text: To hold that article 22 5  requires that, wherever detention is grounded on alleged prejudicial speeches, the detaining authority should indicate to the person detained the passages which it regards as objectionable would rob the provisions of the Act of much of their usefulness in the very class of cases where those provisions were doubtless primarily intended to be used...

arguments.claim: Right to representation illusory without particulars of verbal acts (speeches)

anchor.surface_text: But how can anyone give a fair explanation of his companyduct unless he is told with reasonable plainness what he has done, and in the case of a speech, the words used are everything. They have been called verbal acts in another companynection.

holdings.text: Preventive detention under section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950 is governed by Articles 21 and 22 of the Constitution and not by Article 19(1)(a), notwithstanding that it abridges the right to freedom of speech.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the petitions number before us are governed by the decision in Gopalans case 1950 S.C.R. 88, 100-101, number withstanding that the petitioners right under article 19 1 a is abridged as a result of their detention under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Gopalan precedent distinguishing personal liberty deprivation under Arts 21/22 from Art 19 freedoms; no conflict with Romesh Thappar or Brij Bhushan as those concern direct restrictions on speech, not detention.

holdings.text: The grounds of detention communicated under section 7 contain sufficient particulars (time, place, general nature and effect of speeches) to enable effective representation under Article 22(5); gist or offending passages of speeches not required.

anchor.surface_text: the grounds companymunicated to the petitioners companytain sufficient particulars to enable them to make their representations to the authority companycerned, and that the requirements of article 22 5 have thus been companyplied with.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Atma Ram Vaidya requiring particulars for representation but not mandating gist of speeches; test is sufficiency for representation; policy consideration that requiring gist would undermine Act in confidential speech cases.

holdings.text: Detention orders need not specify the period of detention as section 12 of the Act prescribes a maximum of one year, rendering them not indefinite.

anchor.surface_text: This point is number companycluded against the petitioners by the decision of this Court in Ujager Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 149 of 1950 and Jagjit Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 167 of 1950 where it was pointed out that as section 12 of the Act itself prescribed a maximum period of one year for detention thereunder, such orders companyld number be said to be of indefinite duration and unlawful on that ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly follows Ujager Singh and Jagjit Singh precedents applying section 12.

holdings.text: No mala fides established in the detention orders; District Magistrate's affidavit denial sufficient absent proof by petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: We have thus allegations on the one side and denial on the other, and the petitioners made numberattempt to discharge the burden, which undoubtedly lay upon them, to prove that the District Magistrate acted mala fide in issuing the orders of detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden on petitioners to prove mala fides not discharged; affidavit credibly denies collateral purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions are dismissed.

holdings.text: Grounds of detention are vague and insufficient without substance or gist of speeches, violating Article 22(5); detentions illegal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above I venture to dissent from the opinion of the majority of the Court with great respect and hold that the detention orders above mentioned are illegal. I accordingly order the release of the petitioners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Atma Ram Vaidya strictly; analogy to IPC charges requiring substance; public speeches demand particulars for effective representation; no privilege claimed.

holdings.text: Detentions illegal due to insufficient grounds under Article 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: Bose, J. I agree with my brother Mahajan whose judgment I have had the advantage of reading, and with the utmost respect find myself unable to accept the majority view. I am of opinion that these petitioners should all be released on the ground that their detentions are illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with Mahajan; particulars essential for speeches as verbal acts; illustrative errors possible without gist.

precedents.citation: A. K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras 1950 S.C.R. 88

anchor.surface_text: A. K. Gopalan v. The State of Madras 1950 S.C.R. 88 that the provisions of section 3 of the Act were companystitutional and valid, detention under that section was ultra vires and illegal where, as here, it was based on the ground of making speeches prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order.

precedents.case_name: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of section 3 of the Preventive Detention Act are constitutional and valid; Article 19 does not apply to laws authorising deprivation of personal liberty under Articles 21 and 22
precedents.cited_holding: a law which authorises deprivation of personal liberty did not fall within the purview of article 19

precedents.citation: Brij Bhushan and Another v. The State of Delhi 1950 S.C.R. 605

anchor.surface_text: Brij Bhushan and Another v. The State of Delhi 1950 S.C.R. 605 and Romesh Thappar v. The State of Madras 1950 S.C.R. 594. This contention was rejected on the ground that no such proviso could be read into section 3 on the strength of the later decisions referred to above which related to a different point, viz., the scope of authorised restrictions on the right to freedom of speech conferred by article 19(1).

precedents.cited_proposition: restrictions on freedom of speech not authorised for maintenance of public order

precedents.cited_proposition: restrictions on freedom of speech not authorised for maintenance of public order

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Atma Ram Sridhar Vaidya
precedents.cited_proposition: grounds of detention must provide sufficient particulars to enable effective representation under Article 22(5); vagueness is justiciable
precedents.cited_holding: the sufficiency of this second communication of particulars was a justiciable issue

precedents.citation: Ujager Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 149 of 1950

anchor.surface_text: Ujager Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 149 of 1950 and Jagjit Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 167 of 1950 where it was pointed out that as section 12 of the Act itself prescribed a maximum period of one year for detention thereunder, such orders could not be said to be of indefinite duration and unlawful on that ground.

precedents.case_name: Ujager Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: detention orders not invalid for not specifying period as section 12 prescribes maximum of one year

precedents.citation: Jagjit Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 167 of 1950

anchor.surface_text: Jagjit Singh v. The State of Punjab Petition No. 167 of 1950 where it was pointed out that as section 12 of the Act itself prescribed a maximum period of one year for detention thereunder, such orders could not be said to be of indefinite duration and unlawful on that ground.

precedents.case_name: Jagjit Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: detention orders not invalid for not specifying period as section 12 prescribes maximum of one year

precedents.cited_proposition: grounds must be sufficient to enable detained person to make effective representation
precedents.cited_holding: if the representation has to be intelligible to meet the charges contained in the grounds, the information conveyed to the detained person must be sufficient to attain that object
